text: Family Member: Yeah, uh hum. Doctor: We know a lot about the side effects. Family Member: Well with having chemotherapy, would that be, I know it’s not the same drug, but the same effect like I had chemotherapy for breast cancer? Doctor: Yes, we use one drug. We use Taxotere. So I don’t which ones you got. Family Member: I had Adriamycin and Cytoxan. Doctor: Yeah, it’s a little bit different. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: We think it’s probably a little bit better tolerated because we’re only giving one drug Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: than it is you know the hair loss, the nausea, the vomiting, Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: you know the numbness of the fingertips, excess tearing, you know changes in blood counts, that you’re at risk for infection, can cause liver injury, nausea, things that you feel

text: Patient: I’ve been fine since then. Doctor: And you’re still on the low dose right? Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Now your doctor wanted to get you off the prednisone and try Cymbalta? Patient: Well he mentioned, well he was asking me about stuff and I was telling him about the you know the blah, blah, blah. Doctor: Yeah that you’re on. Patient: And he’s said he’s had good luck with other patients that have had pain with that Cymbalta. Doctor: In the joints? I mean I don’t know how it will help with that with your pain, but you know what it’s definitely worth a try. I have no objections to giving that a try but I’m not terribly hopeful, but if he’s seen something different in his experience. Patient: Well if that’s the case I’ll just stay on the prednisone. text: Patient: All of whom. All of whom. All eight, including the, the black guy who did this study from Harvard, were convinced that they had Native American, uh, genes. None. (Laughs) Doctor: Well, you know, I, I did this myself. Ancest--I did Ancestry. Patient: Yeah. I might do that. Doctor: And, uh, I don’t know what they. I don’t know enough about what they use as a marker to say you’re --- Patient: Yeah, x-y-or z. Doctor: I want to say, I think Native American, there’s certain mutations that might come up that are only in Native American population. So, anyway, my, my story was my, my name is D_. My, there’s a town in England called D_. I had done my genealogy back to eighteen twenty. Until, you know, my --- two generations ago came to America, multiple generations lived in England. Patient: Do you know that for sure? Doctor: Were married to people in England, had children in England. So, I’m English, right? And, then, my moth --- my grandmother’s German. My grandfather is English. So I’m going to do my Ancestry.com just to confirm, um, you know, those are my things. Family Member: I betcha you’re German, like us, yeah. Doctor: No English. I don’t even know how it’s possible because Doctor: It came back, like, I was German. My mother is Italian. That was there. The German was there, but it didn’t even mention English. And then, there was a little note, saying, “A low probability, four percent, English.” Like, no, that’s impossible because, English, English, English, English. Doctor: I see all of this, and I’m like, hmmm, I wonder if one of my great grandfathers is not English. (Laughs) Patient: He might have been a Norman.

text: Family Member: I can. I mean whatever I need to do, just let me know. I’ll do it. (pause) Doctor: Yeah um. Do you want to talk to him soon?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
